user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
...
void OS_printf(const char *String, ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    msg_buffer[OS_BUFFER_SIZE];
    int     actualsz;

    BUGCHECK_VOID(String != NULL)

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        /*
         * Catch some historical mis-use of the OS_printf() call.
         *
         * Typically OS_printf() should NOT be called before OS_API_Init().
         *
         * This was never guaranteed to work, particularly on a VxWorks
         * deployment where the utility task was enabled.
         *
         * However, some PSPs do this, particularly those that used POSIX
         * where it happened to work (because OS_printf just called printf).
         *
         * As a workaround, use the OS_DEBUG facility to dump the message,
         * along with a clue that this API is being used inappropriately.
         *
         * If debugging is not enabled, then this message will be silently
         * discarded.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("BUG: OS_printf() called when OSAL not initialized: %s", String);
    }
    else if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfEnabled)
    {
        /* Format and determine the size of string to write */
        va_start(va, String);
        actualsz = vsnprintf(msg_buffer, sizeof(msg_buffer), String, va);
        va_end(va);

        if (actualsz < 0)
        {
            /* unlikely: vsnprintf failed */
            actualsz = 0;
        }
        else if (actualsz >= OS_BUFFER_SIZE)
        {
            /* truncate */
            actualsz = OS_BUFFER_SIZE - 1;
        }

        msg_buffer[actualsz] = 0;

        OS_ConsoleWrite(OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfConsoleId, msg_buffer);
    }
}
...
#define OS_INVALID_POINTER (-2)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have reported locations that should be investigated for possible unreachable code because they involve macros or constructs that may produce non-local control flow (BUGCHECK / BUGCHECK_VOID / ARGCHECK / OS_CHECK_*), or they perform array-indexing based on a size argument that might be constrained by other code paths. These are the places where unreachable code is most likely to be introduced due to abort/return behavior of the macros or to assumptions about parameter ranges.

Other fragments in the provided code were not included because they are simple constant definitions, straightforward return statements, local variable declarations, or normal conditional branches whose reachability does not depend on the non-local behavior of the macros. For example, the definitions of OS_SUCCESS and OS_INVALID_POINTER, the local declarations of return_code, the gethostname() conditional structure (apart from the sentinel assignment already flagged), and the UtAssert_Abort function body as given do not by themselves indicate unreachable code without further macro/implementation details; they therefore do not require investigation for Rule 2.1 in this context. If deeper macro definitions (e.g. exact expansion of BUGCHECK/BUGCHECK_VOID/ARGCHECK) or attributes indicating non-return were provided, additional fragments might need to be added, so the listed fragments are the conservative set to examine first.
